conclusion: At t = 0, Car A starts with the lower speed v₁, Car B with the higher speed v₂.
The two curves cross once, so at that instant the two cars have the same speed.
The slope of any v–t curve gives the instantaneous acceleration.
Look at the steepness (slope) of each curve as time progresses.
If a curve becomes progressively flatter, |slope| is getting smaller → |a| is decreasing.
If a curve becomes progressively steeper, |slope| is getting larger → |a| is increasing.
Car A: the slope is largest near t = 0 and becomes smaller as t → t₁ (the curve flattens).

premise: Car A: the slope is largest near t = 0 and becomes smaller as t → t₁ (the curve flattens).

conclusion: Car B: the slope is smallest near t = 0 and becomes larger as t → t₁ (the curve gets steeper).

premise: Car B: the slope is smallest near t = 0 and becomes larger as t → t₁ (the curve gets steeper).

conclusion: During the interval 0 ≤ t ≤ t₁ the magnitude of Car A’s acceleration steadily decreases, whereas the magnitude of Car B’s acceleration steadily increases.
